title: Pizza Hut and the Freedom of Small Houses
html:
Homepage
Homepage
Food
Become a memberSign inGet started

Dining Out

Pizza Hut and the Freedom of Small Houses

Hanif Abdurraqib
Oct 2, 2017
Loading…
0:00
7:28

The Pizza Hut coupons encased the coupon pamphlets that would invade my family’s mailbox every week. Most were useless to us: some furniture ads or pamphlets about cars we could never afford. We would peel off the Pizza Hut coupons and leave the rest. The deals didn’t change too often, but every now and then there would be a slight difference in the weekly offerings. Maybe two large pizzas for $13, a few extra toppings instead of just the usual one. Maybe a stuffed-crust pizza for slightly less than the 10 bucks it would usually go for. We’d cut out the coupons that seemed like they’d be the most useful and stuffed them in a drawer.

Growing up, my family didn’t have a lot of money. Even though this is true, it does bear pointing out that there are different levels of poverty, and we lived in the level at which there were small mercies and joys that could be afforded at the end of a long working week. In the case of my family, this meant pizza every Friday. During the rest of the week, we often cooked our own meals at home — something both my mother and father insisted that my siblings and I learn at a young age. But on Fridays, we would go to the coupon drawer, pick out a coupon, and order pizza. At its most packed, my childhood home fit both of my parents, my grandmother, me, and my three siblings. What Pizza Hut provided — more than any level of high quality — was a quantity level that could feed our family at a reasonable price. A little over $20 and you’d have three large pizzas, sometimes breadsticks. My brother and I would sit with our knees on the couch facing the window and wait eagerly for the delivery driver to do his familiar slowing down on our block before tentatively turning into our driveway. Though they aren’t made like this anymore, back then the pizzas from Pizza Hut (and several other places) would have a small white circle in the middle to secure the pizza during deliveries. My brother and I would take them out of the box and build small white houses with them.

I have a problem that is frustrating to most of my friends and deeply confusing to others. It’s one that I can’t really help, and it’s somewhat rare among most people I know. I can tell the difference between bad pizza and average pizza, but I have a significantly harder time telling the difference between average pizza and good (or even great) pizza. It’s a major roadblock for me, but it’s also oddly freeing. I imagine most pizza as simply fine. And once it gets to a certain level of fine, it’s all that level of fine. There are several reasons for this, I imagine: I grew up in central Ohio, which — unlike Chicago or New York — isn’t defined by a single specific type of pizza. There are largely only pizza chains that offer some variation on the same exact model. This isn’t bad, mind you. I love all of central Ohio’s pizza: the grease-soaked garlic crust of Hounddog’s; the square, thin, and crustless Donatos; the old standbys like Domino’s and Pizza Hut. I do not love Papa John’s, though I do appreciate how it dragged me through some of my more impoverished college moments.

But I did live in Connecticut for two and a half years—a place where pizza is pretty much all the state has to claim for itself. I lived a mere three blocks from the legendary Frank Pepe’s pizza place, known worldwide for its white clam pizza, rated the number one pizza in America several times. It made me wonder what went into such rankings and who was the final decider of a pizza’s fate. Still, the line at Frank Pepe’s would snake around the block on weekends, weekday evenings, and sometimes even weekday afternoons. When my friends came to visit, they would eagerly ask to be taken down the street to the legendary pizza place. Even if we couldn’t get in, there was an abundance of other places to stop in: Modern Apizza, just a short walk from my door. Or Sally’s Pizza, across from Frank Pepe’s, constantly battling for relevance against its significantly more popular sibling. Connecticut pizza is, decidedly, its own thing. Thin crust, wood-fired. The emphasis is entirely on the cooking of the pizza, and then the sauce. The cheese and toppings are almost perfunctory. I’m sure that, to some, this is pizza as it should be done.

There were pizza chains in my part of Connecticut, but they were few and far between. Some tucked into corners, and others dumped onto long strips of road where all the other chains were vomited out. Next to the shopping mall, there’s a Wendy’s and a McDonald’s and a KFC and a Papa John’s and a Domino’s and a Boston Market all crammed into the same space, as if to say, “Come here for that which is not good enough for our other neighborhoods.”

The thing is — and I’m sure there is a part of this that is failing to take account for the majestic work of Connecticut pizza — it all tasted the same to me. Or perhaps worse. When I first bit into Frank Pepe’s pizza, I noticed only that the crust had been (what I considered) burned, the black of it flaking off and staining my fingertips. I get that this is a part of the experience: the elements of the full meal, leaving behind their traces on your skin. I want to say that it is a failure of my taste buds, which grew up tethered to the simple joys of chain pizza places. But I want a simple and fat crust, perhaps with cheese melted inside it.

Living in Connecticut taught me a new way to miss home every week. None of these ways, though, stung like the black crust staining my fingers, or the pizza cut in uneven slices, while everyone around the table cheered its name and I longed for something else.

I think what I’m saying, friends, is that some meals work their way into your lineage and don’t work their way out. It’s good to have a timeline you can go back to, and mine begins with Pizza Hut, and a part of it ends there.

In the final photo of my mother before her death, she is not looking at the camera. I’m sure if she had known it would be the last picture ever taken of her, she’d have looked at the camera and flashed her impossible smile. That’s the way it works, I suppose. No one knows what may be their last until it ends up being their last. Instead, she is sitting next to my sister, both in white hijabs, at a table. My mother is holding a pitcher of Sprite and looks like she is giving directions to the table—most likely to my brother and me, both of us on the verge of being teens at the time and surely giving her all that she could handle. The picture was taken at a Pizza Hut in Cincinnati, Ohio. We had just finished watching my oldest brother graduate college and decided to celebrate at a nearby Pizza Hut. It wasn’t a Friday, but it was still worth the small luxury to dive into in celebration. No one in my family had ever graduated college before, and my mother was glowing.

I don’t remember the nuances of the day or what was on the pizzas. But the picture stands out for what it speaks into the air about closeness and distance. The way how even in this still shot that she didn’t know was being taken, my mother was trying to gather everyone around a meal that had just arrived. I don’t look at that picture anymore. I don’t know where it is in my old house, but I know it is there. We didn’t get pizza on Friday as often after my mother died. It all felt different.

This is mostly about food and ghosts and how one, if we’re lucky, can drag us closer to the other. I haven’t eaten Pizza Hut in so long that I can’t even recall the taste of it. I do think, often, about the small white houses my brother and I would build out of the pizza box accessories. I think about what those might say about a type of freedom we were being afforded. Poor, but still able to buy this brief and greasy luxury. Poor, but still born into a family who knew how to spin a Friday night into a longer joy. Poor, and building an imaginary space where everyone we love might just make it after all.

written by

Hanif Abdurraqib

Poet. Writer. | Poetry editor @MuzzleMagazine | Author of The Crown Ain't Worth Much & They Can’t Kill Us Until They Kill Us. | Ohioan

title_html: Pizza Hut and the Freedom of Small Houses
